internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Does the solution of this problem prove that the result is exact?

worksheet.stem:
The following data come from a table that was measured with high precision. Use the best numerical method to determine y for the second order at x = 3.5. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

x 0 1.8 5 6 8.2 9.2 12
y 26 16.415 5.375 3.5 2.015 2.54 8

 

The value of y is __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Order points and then develop a divided difference table:

 

x y First Second Third Fourth Fifth Sixth
5 5.375 –3.45 0.375 –2.2E–17 1.51788E–18 7.54895E–19 –2.57192E–19
1.8 16.415 –3.075 0.375 –1.7E–17 4.68844E–18 –1.04545E–18  
6 3.5 –3.75 0.375 1.73E–17 –5.97516E–18    
0 26 –2.925 0.375 –1.9E–17      
8.2 2.015 0.525 0.375        
9.2 2.54 1.95          
12 8            

 

Notice that it was unnecessary to build the whole table because after the fourth point, the third derivative is essentially zero. This means that the data would be perfectly described by a quadratic.

 

Zero order

 

%media:formula66.mml%

 

%media:formula1.mml%

 

First order

 

%media:formula67.mml%

 

%media:formula2.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula68.mml%

 

%media:formula3.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which type of table is used for generating Newton interpolation polynomial with the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Consider the data:

 

x 0 1 2.5 3 4.5 5 6
y 2 5.4375 7.3516 7.5625 8.4453 9.1875 12

 

Use Newton’s interpolating polynomial and the data to determine y for the third order at x = 3.5 to the best possible accuracy. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of y = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
First order points and then develop a divided difference table:

 

x y First Second Third Fourth
3 7.5625 0.588533 0.083367 0.145827 –7.61905E–06
4.5 8.4453 0.54685 0.37502 0.145842  
2.5 7.3516 0.73436 –0.13543    
5 9.1875 0.9375      
1 5.4375        

 

Zero order

 

%media:formula69.mml%

 

%media:formula4.mml%

 

First order

 

%media:formula70.mml%

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula71.mml%

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula72.mml%

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

Fourth order

%media:formula8.mml%

Use Newton's interpolating polynomial and the data to determine y for fourth order at x = 8 to the best possible accuracy. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

sectionBreak.stem:
The given table lists values for dissolved oxygen concentration (mg/L) in water as a function of temperature (°C)  and chloride concentration (g/L).

 

T, °C c = 0 g/L c = 10 g/L c = 20 g/L
0 14.6 12.9 11.4
5 12.8 11.3 10.3
10 11.3 10.1 8.96
15 10.1 9.03 8.08
20 9.09 8.17 7.35
25 8.26 7.46 6.73
30 7.56 6.85 6.20

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The oxygen concentration using quadratic interpolation is 9.6564 mg/L.

 

The oxygen concentration using cubic interpolation is 9.6519 mg/L.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the recursive nature of finite divided difference for the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Use quadratic and cubic interpolation to determine the oxygen concentration for T = 12 °C and c = 10 g/L. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The oxygen concentration using quadratic interpolation is __a__ mg/L.

 

The oxygen concentration using cubic interpolation is __b__ mg/L.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The points can be ordered so that they are close to and centered around the unknown. A divided difference table can then be developed as follows:

 

T, °C c = 10 g/L first second third
10 10.1 –0.214 0.0026 0.000107
15 9.03 –0.227 0.003667  
5 11.3 –0.20867    
20 8.17      

 

Second order

 

%media:formula79.mml%

 

%media:formula48.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula80.mml%

 

%media:formula49.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to fit the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Employ inverse interpolation using a cubic interpolating polynomial and bisection to determine the value of x that corresponds to f (x) = 1.7 for the given data. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

x 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
f(x) 3.6 1.8 1.2 0.9 0.72 1.5 0.51429

 

The value of x = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
MATLAB can be used to generate a cubic polynomial through the first 4 points in the table,

 

>> x = [1 2 3 4]; fx = [3.6 1.8 1.2 0.9];
>> p = polyfit(x,fx,3)
p =
   -0.1500 1.5000 -5.2500 7.5000

 

Therefore, the roots problem to be solved is

 

%media:formula64.mml%

or

 

%media:formula65.mml%

 

Bisection can be employed to find the root of this polynomial. Using initial guesses of xl = 2 and xu = 3, a value of 2.1009 is obtained with εa = 0.00069% after 16 iterations. Alternatively, MATLAB yields the same result:

 

>> p(4)= p(4)-1.7;
>> x = roots(p)
x =
   3.9495 + 1.6751i
   3.9495 - 1.6751i
   2.1009

Analytically

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function can be used to fit the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Use quadratic interpolation and the quadratic formula to determine numerically the value of x that corresponds to f (x) = 0.93 for the given data. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of x = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
A quadratic interpolating polynomial can be fit to the last three points using the polyfit function,

 

>> format long
>> x = [3 4 5];
>> y = x.^2./(1+x.^2);
>> p = polyfit(x,y,2)
p =
  -0.01040723981900   0.11402714932127   0.65158371040724

 

Thus, the best fit quadratic is as follows:

 

%media:formula30.mml%

 

Therefore, to find the root of f(x), steps are as follows:

 

%media:formula31.mml%

or

%media:formula32.mml%

 

The quadratic formula yields

 

%media:formula33.mml%

Thus, the estimate is 3.67294.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function can be used to fit the last four points?

worksheet.stem:
Use cubic interpolation and bisection to determine numerically the value of x that corresponds to f (x) = 0.93 for the given data. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of x = __a__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
A cubic interpolating polynomial can be fit to the last four points using the polyfit function,

 

>> format long
>> x = [2 3 4 5];
>> y=x.^2./(1+x.^2)
>> p = polyfit(x,y,3)
p =
   0.00633484162896    -0.08642533936652    0.41176470588235    0.27149321266968

 

Thus, the best fit cubic is as follows:

 

%media:formula34.mml%

 

The root of f(x) can be computed as follows:

 

%media:formula35.mml%

or

 

%media:formula36.mml%

 

Bisection can be employed to find the root of this polynomial. Using initial guesses of xl = 3 and xu = 4, a value of 3.61883 is obtained.

sectionBreak.stem:
Consider the steam table:

 

v, m3/kg 0.10377 0.11144 0.12547
s, kJ/(kg K) 6.4147 6.5453 6.7664

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of s is 6.6487 kJ/(kg K).

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which pair of values bracket the unknown entropy?

worksheet.stem:
Use the portion of the given steam table for super-heated water at 200 MPa to find the corresponding entropy s for a specific volume v of 0.118 with linear interpolation. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of s = __a__kJ/(kg K).
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Because they bracket the unknown, the last two points are used for linear interpolation,

 

%media:formula62.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of s is 6.6515 kg/ m3.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to find entropy using quadratic interpolation?

worksheet.stem:
Use the portion of the given steam table for superheated water at 200 MPa to find the corresponding entropy using quadratic interpolation. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of s = __a__ kJ/(kg K).
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The quadratic interpolation can be implemented easily in MATLAB,

 

>> v = [0.10377 0.11144 0.12547];
>> s = [6.4147 6.5453 6.7664];
>> p = polyfit(v,s,2)
p =
   -58.4466 29.6057 3.9719
>> polyval(p,0.118)
ans =
   6.6515

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of the specific volume corresponding to an entropy of 6.45 is 0.1058 m<sup>3</sup>.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the equation of quadratic polynomial for the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Use the portion of the given steam table for superheated water at 200 MPa to find the volume corresponding to an entropy of 6.45 using inverse interpolation. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of v = __a__ m3/kg.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The inverse interpolation can be implemented in MATLAB. First, fit a quadratic polynomial to the data to yield s = –58.4466v2 + 29.6057v + 3.9719. Therefore the root of the following equation must be found.

 

%media:formula63.mml%

 

or

 

%media:formula81.mml%

 

In MATLAB, this polynomial can be generated by subtracting 6.45 from the constant coefficient of the polynomial

 

>> p(3)=p(3)-6.45
p =
   -58.4466 29.6057 -2.4781

 

Then, we can use the roots function to determine the solution,

 

>> roots(p)
ans =
    0.4007
    0.1058

 

Thus, the value of the specific volume corresponding to an entropy of 6.45 is 0.1058 m3.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
The given data for the density of nitrogen gas versus temperature come from a table that was measured with high precision.

 

T, K 200 250 300 350 400 450
Density, kg/m3 1.708 1.367 1.139 0.967 0.854 0.759

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The density at a temperature of 330 K = 1.029 kg/m<sup>3</sup>.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How to generate divided difference table for the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Use first- through fifth-order polynomials to estimate the density at a temperature of 330 K. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The density at a temperature of 330 K = __a__Kg/m3.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
This problem is nicely suited for the Newton interpolating polynomial. First, the data can be ordered so that the points are closest to and centered around the unknown,

 

T D
300 1.139
350 0.967
400 0.854
250 1.367
450 0.759
200 1.708

 

Then the divided difference table can be generated as follows:

 

T D first second third fourth fifth
300 1.139 –0.003440 1.18000E–05 4.00000E–09 –2.93333E–10 –2.77333E–12
350 0.967 –0.002260 1.16000E–05 –4.00000E–08 –1.60000E–11  
400 0.854 –0.003420 7.60000E–06 –3.76000E–08    
250 1.367 –0.003040 1.51200E–05      
450 0.759 –0.003796        
200 1.708          

 

First-order (linear) fit

 

%media:formula57.mml%

 

Thus, the linear estimate is 1.036 to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

Second-order (quadratic) fit

 

%media:formula58.mml%

 

The quadratic estimate is 1.029 to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

Third-order (cubic) fit:

 

%media:formula59.mml%

 

The cubic estimate is also 1.029.

Fourth-order (quartic) fit

 

%media:formula60.mml%

 

The quartic estimate now seems to be diverging slightly by moving to a value of 1.028. This may be an initial indication that the higher-order terms are beginning to induce slight oscillations.

Fifth-order (quintic) fit

 

%media:formula61.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value: The quartic estimate seems to be diverging slightly by moving to a value of 1.0279. The cubic equation provides the best approximation and that a value of 1.0288 is a sound estimate to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: False, the cubic equation provides the best approximation for the given problem.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the value of third-order fit in the given problem?

trueFalse.stem: The quartic equation provides the best approximation for the given problem.
trueFalse.commonFeedback: The quartic estimate seems to be diverging slightly by moving to a value of 1.0279. The cubic equation provides the best approximation and that a value of 1.0288 is a sound estimate to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

trueInfo.feedback: The quartic estimate seems to be diverging slightly by moving to a value of 1.0279. The cubic equation provides the best approximation and that a value of 1.0288 is a sound estimate to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

falseInfo.feedback: The quartic estimate seems to be diverging slightly by moving to a value of 1.0279. The cubic equation provides the best approximation and that a value of 1.0288 is a sound estimate to the level of significant digits provided in the original data.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the value of density obtained from the previous part?

hint.name: hint #2
hint.value: How can the temperature be found using MATLAB with the given data?

worksheet.stem:
Employ the best estimate and inverse interpolation to determine the corresponding temperature. (Round the final answer to the nearest whole number.)

 

The temperature T is __a__ K.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Inverse interpolation can be now used to determine the temperature corresponding to the value of density of 1.029. First, MATLAB can be used to fit a cubic polynomial through the four points that bracket this value. Interestingly, because of the large values of the temperatures, we get an error message,

 

>> T = [250 300 350 400];
>> D =[1.3670 1.139 0.967 0.854];
>> p = polyfit(T,D,3)
Warning: Polynomial is badly conditioned. Remove repeated data points or try centering and scaling as described in HELP POLYFIT.
(Type "warning off MATLAB:polyfit:RepeatedPointsOrRescale" to suppress this warning.)
> In polyfit at 78
p =
   0.0000  0.0000  -0.0097  3.2420

 

Let’s disregard this warning and proceed to adjust the polynomial so that it can be used to solve the inverse interpolation problem. To do this, subtract the specified value of the density from the polynomial’s constant coefficient:

 

>> p(4)=p(4)-1.029
p =
   0.0000  0.0000  -0.0097  2.2130

 

Then we can use the roots function to determine the temperature that corresponds to this value

 

>> roots(p)
ans =
 1.0e+003 *
   -2.8237
   0.5938
   0.3300

 

Thus, even though the polynomial is badly conditioned, one of the roots corresponds to T = 330 as expected.


Now let’s perform the inverse interpolation, but with scaling. To do this, we will first merely subtract the value at the midpoint of the temperature range (325) from all the temperatures. This acts to both reduce the magnitudes of the temperatures and centers them on zero.

 

>> format long
>> D = [1.3670 1.139 0.967 0.854];
>> T = [250 300 350 400];
>> T = T - 325;

 

Then, the cubic fit can be generated with no error message,

 

>> p = polyfit(T,D,3)
p =
  0.00000000400000   0.00001150000000 -0.00344250000000         1.04581250000000

 

We can set up the roots problem as follows:

 

>> p(4)=p(4)-1.029
p =
  0.00000000400000   0.00001150000000       -0.00344250000000       0.01681250000000

 

We can then use the roots function to determine the temperature that corresponds to the given density

 

>> r = roots(p)
ans =
    1.0e+003 *
     -3.14874694489127
     0.26878060289231
     0.00496634199799

By adding back the offset of 325, we arrive at the expected result of 330,

 

>> Tinv=r(3)+325
Tinv =
     3.299663419979927e+002

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Bessel functions often arise in advanced engineering analyses such as the study of electric fields. Consider some values for the zero-order Bessel function of the first kind

 

x 1.8 2.0 2.2 2.4 2.6
J1(x) 0.5815 0.5767 0.5560 0.5202 0.4708

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of J1(2.1) using third-order interpolating polynomials is 0.5683, and the value of J1(2.1) using fourth-order interpolating polynomials is 0.5683.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to generate the cubic polynomial?

worksheet.stem:
Estimate J1(2.1) using third- and fourth-order interpolating polynomials. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The value of J1(2.1) using third-order interpolating polynomials = __a__.

The value of J1(2.1) using fourth-order interpolating polynomials = __b__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Third-order case

 

The MATLAB polyfit function can be used to generate the cubic polynomial and perform the interpolation,

 

>> x = [1.8 2 2.2 2.4];
>> J = [0.5815 0.5767 0.5560 0.5202];
>> p = polyfit(x,J,3)
p =
   0.0167   -0.2988   0.9306   -0.2228
>> Jpred=polyval(p,2.1)
Jpred =
      0.5683

 

Fourth-order case

 

>> x = [1.8 2 2.2 2.4 2.6];
>> J = [0.5815 0.5767 0.5560 0.5202 0.4708];
>> p = polyfit(x,J,4)
p =
   0.0182 -0.1365 0.1818 0.2630 0.1237
>> Jpred=polyval(p,2.1)
Jpred =
      0.5683

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The percent relative error for the third-order case is 8.1573×10<sup>–4</sup>%, and the percent relative error for the fourth-order case is 0.0021%.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can besselj function be written to find the percent error?

worksheet.stem:
Determine the percent relative error for third- and fourth-order case based on the true value, which can be determined with MATLAB’s built-in function besselj. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The percent relative error for the third-order case is __a__×10–4 %.

The percent relative error for the fourth-order case is __b__%.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Third-order case

The built-in function besselj can be employed to determine the true value which can then be used to determine the percent relative error.

 

>> Jtrue=besselj(1,2.1)
Jtrue =
    0.5683
>> ea=abs((Jtrue-Jpred)/Jtrue)*100
ea =
    8.1573e-004

 

Fourth-order case

 

>> ea=abs((Jtrue-Jpred)/Jtrue)*100
ea =
   0.0021

sectionBreak.stem:
The population in millions of the United States from 1920 to 2000 can be tabulated as follows:

 

Date 1920 1930 1940 1950 1960 1970 1980 1990 2000
Population 106.46 123.08 132.12 152.27 180.67 205.05 227.23 249.46 281.42

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The values can be tabulated as

 

First order 271.69
Second order 271.74
Third order 273.99
Fourth order 274.42

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Can MATLAB be used to predict the population in 2000?

worksheet.stem:
Use first-, second-, third-, and fourth-order interpolating polynomials to predict the population in 2000 based on the most recent data. That is, for the linear prediction use the data from 1980 and 1990, for the quadratic prediction use the data from 1970, 1980, and 1990, and so on. (Round the final answers to two decimal places.)

 

The values can be tabulated as

 

First order __a__
Second order __b__
Third order __c__
Fourth order __d__
worksheet.commonFeedback:
MATLAB can be used to evaluate each of the cases.

 

First order


>> t = [1990 1980];
>> pop = [249.46 227.23];
>> ts = (t - 1955)/35;
>> p = polyfit(ts,pop,1);
>> polyval(p,(2000-1955)/35)


ans =
     271.6900

 

Second order

 

>> t = [t 1970];
>> pop = [pop 205.05];
>> ts = (t - 1955)/35;
>> p = polyfit(ts,pop,2);
>> polyval(p,(2000-1955)/35)


ans =
     271.7400

 

Third order

 

>> t = [t 1960];
>> pop = [pop 180.67];
>> ts = (t - 1955)/35;
>> p = polyfit(ts,pop,3);
>> polyval(p,(2000-1955)/35)


ans =
     273.9900

 

Fourth order

 

>> t = [t 1950];
>> pop = [pop 152.27];
>> ts = (t - 1955)/35;
>> p = polyfit(ts,pop,4);
>> polyval(p,(2000-1955)/35)


ans =
     274.4200

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
The solution obtained can be tabulated as

 

First order 271.69
Second order 271.74
Third order 273.99
Fourth order 274.42

 

It can be observed that the addition of each term causes the prediction for 2000 to increase. Thus, using higher-order approximations is moving the prediction closer to the actual value of 281.42 that occurred in 2000.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The value of v at T = 400°C is 9.3521 L/kg.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which numerical method is used to find the value of v?

worksheet.stem:
The specific volume of a superheated steam is listed in steam tables for various temperatures.

 

T, °C 370 382 394 406 418
v, L/kg 5.9313 7.5838 8.8428 9.796 10.5311

 

Determine v at T = 400°C. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The value of v = __a__L/kg.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
This problem is ideally suited for Newton interpolation. First, order the points so that they are as close to and as centered about the unknown as possible.

x0 = 394           f(x0) = 8.8428

x1 = 406           f(x1) = 9.796

x2 = 382           f(x2) = 7.5838

x3 = 418           f(x3) = 10.5311

x4 = 370           f(x4) = 5.9313

 

Then we can generate the divided difference table,

 

T v first second third fourth
394 8.8428 0.079433 –0.00106 8.46 × 10–6 9.95264 × 10–21
406 9.7960 0.092175 –0.00086 8.46 × 10–6  
382 7.5838 0.081869 –0.00116    
418 10.5311 0.095829      
370 5.9313        

 

Zero order

 

%media:formula14.mml%

 

First order

 

%media:formula15.mml%

 

Second order

 

%media:formula16.mml%

 

Third order

 

%media:formula17.mml%

 

Fourth order

 

%media:formula18.mml%

 

 Note that the third-order polynomial yields an exact result to 7 significant digits, and so we conclude that the interpolation is 9.3521.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which MATLAB function is used to find σ in this problem?

worksheet.stem:
The vertical stress σz under the corner of a rectangular area subjected to a uniform load of intensity q is given by the solution of Boussinesq’s equation:

 

%media:formula43.mml%

 

Because this equation is inconvenient to solve manually, it has been reformulated as

 

%media:formula44.mml%

 

where fz(m, n) is called the influence value, and m and n are dimensionless ratios, with m = a/z and n = b/z and a and b are defined in the figure below. 

 

%media:p17-16.jpg%

 

The influence value is then tabulated, a portion of which is given in the table:

 

m n = 1.2 n = 1.4 n = 1.6
0.1 0.02926 0.03007 0.03058
0.2 0.05733 0.05894 0.05994
0.3 0.08323 0.08561 0.08709
0.4 0.10631 0.10941 0.11135
0.5 0.12626 0.13003 0.13241
0.6 0.14309 0.14749 0.15027
0.7 0.15703 0.16199 0.16515
0.8 0.16843 0.17389 0.17739

 

If a = 4.6 and b = 14, use a third-order interpolating polynomial to compute σz at a depth 10 m below the corner of a rectangular footing that is subject to a total load of 100 t (metric tons). Note that q is equal to the load per area. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of σz is __a__ tonnes/m2.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
%media:formula45.mml%

Use the following values:

 

x0 = 0.3 → f(x0) = 0.08561

x1 = 0.4 → f(x1) = 0.10941

x2 = 0.5 → f(x2) = 0.13003

x3 = 0.6  → f(x3) = 0.14749

 

MATLAB can be used to perform the interpolation:

 

>> format long
>> x=[0.3 0.4 0.5 0.6];
>> y=[0.08561 0.10941 0.13003 0.14749];
>> a=polyfit(x,y,3)
a =
0.00333333333331 -0.16299999999997 0.35086666666665 -0.00507000000000
>> polyval(a,0.46)
ans =
0.12216232000000

This result can be used to compute the vertical stress:

 

%media:formula46.mml%

 

%media:formula47.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Is the linear regression used to find the value of g?

worksheet.stem:
The acceleration due to gravity at an altitude y above the surface of the earth is given by

 

y, m 0 30000 60000 90000 120000
g, m/s2 9.8100 9.7487 9.6879 9.6278 9.5682

 

Compute g at y = [a] m. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

The value of g is  __a__ m/s2.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Using linear regression gives

 

%media:fig17.19.1.png%

 A prediction of g at [a] m can be made as follows:

 

%media:formula19.mml%

 

Note that it can also use linear interpolation to give as follows:

 

%media:formula83.mml%

 

Quadratic interpolation gives as follows:

 

%media:formula84.mml%

 

Cubic interpolation gives as follows:

 

%media:formula85.mml%

 

Based on all these estimates, the result to 3 significant digits is {{[b]:0.000}} m/s2.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
Temperatures measured at various points on a square heated plate are tabulated as shown in the given table:

 

  x = 0 x = 2 x = 4 x = 6 x = 8
y = 0 100.00 90.00 80.00 70.00 60.00
y = 2 85.00 64.49 53.50 48.15 50.00
y = 4 70.00 48.90 38.43 38.43 40.00
y = 6 55.00 38.78 30.39 30.39 30.00
y = 8 40.00 35.00 30.00 30.00 20.00

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which numerical method is well-suited for this problem?

worksheet.stem:
Estimate the temperature at x = 4 and y = 3.2 using the given data. (Round the final answer to three decimal places.)

 

Temperature = __a__°C.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
This part of the problem is well-suited for Newton interpolation. First, order the points so that they are as close to and as centered about the unknown as possible, for x = 4.

y0 = 4                f(y0) = 38.43

y1 = 2                f(y1) = 53.5

y2 = 6                f(y2) = 30.39

y3 = 0                f(y3) = 80

y4 = 8                f(y4) = 30

 

The results of applying Newton’s polynomial at y = 3.2 are as follows:

 

order f(y) Error
0 38.43 6.028
1 44.458 –0.8436
2 43.6144 –0.2464
3 43.368 0.112448
4 13.48045  

The minimum error occurs for the third-order version so we conclude that the interpolation is 43.368 °C.

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Which numerical method is used to find the temperature in this problem?

worksheet.stem:
Estimate the temperature at x = 4.3 and y = 2.7 using the given data. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The temperature is __a__°C.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
This is an example of two-dimensional interpolation. One way to approach it is to use cubic interpolation along the y dimension for values at specific values of x that bracket the unknown. For example, we can utilize the following points at x = 2.

y0 = 0                f(y0) = 90

y1 = 2                f(y1) = 64.49

y2 = 4                f(y2) = 48.9

y3 = 6                f(y3) = 38.78

 

%media:formula37.mml%

 

All the values can be tabulated as follows:

 

%media:formula38.mml%

 

%media:formula39.mml%

 

%media:formula40.mml%

 

%media:formula41.mml%

 

These values can then be used to interpolate at x = 4.3 to yield

 

%media:formula42.mml%

 

Note that some software packages allow you to perform such multi-dimensional interpolations very efficiently. For example, MATLAB has a function interp2 that provides numerous options for how the interpolation is implemented. Here is an example of how it can be implemented using linear interpolation,

 

>> Z=[100 90 80 70 60;
85 64.49 53.5 48.15 50;
70 48.9 38.43 35.03 40;
55 38.78 30.39 27.07 30;
40 35 30 25 20];
>> X=[0 2 4 6 8];
>> Y=[0 2 4 6 8];
>> T=interp2(X,Y,Z,4.3,2.7)

T =
    47.5254

It can also perform the same interpolation but using bicubic interpolation,

 

>> T=interp2(X,Y,Z,4.3,2.7,'cubic')
T =
    46.0062

Finally, the interpolation can be implemented using splines,

 

>> T=interp2(X,Y,Z,4.3,2.7,'spline')
T =
    46.1507

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the formula for inverse interpolation?

worksheet.stem:
Find the volume corresponding to an entropy of 6.6 using inverse interpolation. (Round the final answer to five decimal places.)

 

The value of v = __a__ m3/kg.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
Employ inverse interpolation. First, we fit a quadratic to the data

%media:formula22.mml%

 

The roots problem can then be developed by setting this polynomial equal to the desired value of 6.6 to give

 

%media:formula23.mml%

 

The quadratic formula can then be used to determine the root as follows:

 

%media:formula24.mml%
